question: Hey, Woody, our Mars One crew won't be heading back to Earth till ten days after you guys land at our base camp with Mars Two. That's a pretty good long rendezvous.
answer: What are you suggesting, Sergei?

question: Maybe you should bring a baseball bat. Yes? American baseball? Our two crews could have ourselves a little Solar System Series.
answer: Please. Half you guys are foreigners. We'd crush you.

question: No, no, we have equal crews. Three men, one woman. Same handicap.
answer: Easy now, you're talking about my wife. And Terri just happens to be one helluva shortstop.

question: He's not coming, Luke.
answer: Jim deserves this, too. All his friends are here. And it's my last night.

question: Your last night with us, too.
answer: I love you, Deb.

question: I love you too, baby. But maybe you should spend some time with Bobby.
answer: Yeah. I will. Where is he?

question: We were afraid you wouldn't come.
answer: I caught a whiff of your barbecue. After that I was helpless.

question: All the way out in Galveston?
answer: Something like that. It's his night, Deb. I didn't want to spoil it.

question: C'mon. A whole lot of folks here are gonna be mighty glad to see you.
answer: I wish we were all going. Together.

question: Then you've got a short memory. Think back to how we were by the second week of lunar training.
answer: Oh, you're not gonna bring that up again --

question: I'm trying to remember, let's see, which one of us scored the lowest ranking up there?
answer: You just can't let that go --

question: Oh, man, three commanders, on the same ship? If they sent us off to Mars together, there wouldn't be enough fuel to lift all those egos.
answer: Bullshit, we would've made a great crew.

question: Should've been your mission, Jim. Yours and Maggie's. None of us ever wanted Mars the way you two did. Not even Woody. Twelve years of hoping for this assignment, training for it --
answer: That's all over now.

question: If Maggie hadn't gotten sick -- if you hadn't pulled yourself out of the rotation to take care of her -- No, I'm gonna say this. I have to say it... I wanted Mars One. Hell, I battled you for it every step of the way. Never wanted to beat anybody so bad in my life. But not like this... Jim, I'd give this all up in a second, if it would bring Maggie back to us.
answer: I know that, Luke. You don't have to say it... Mars is yours now. Go get it.

question: Take care of yourself.
answer: Yeah. You too.

question: Well? What's under there?
answer: Je ne sais pas. I... I think there's something wrong with the equipment.

question: What?
answer: I mean, it can't be right. It says... it says there's metal under there. There's ten, twelve meters of rubble and sand, and then... solid metal.

question: That doesn't make any sense. You're reading a vein of ore.
answer: No. It's under the whole mountain.

question: "Problem Okay... Piece of cake. God, who dreams up these nightmares?
answer: Don't try to change the subject.

question: I'm not! We're talking about your sister's wedding, right?
answer: Very funny. We're talking about dancing lessons. Before my sister's wedding.

question: Honey, do you mind? I've got a catastrophic power failure here.
answer: Woody, we're a married couple. Would it kill you to invite me out on the floor once in awhile?

question: I danced with you at our wedding.
answer: I'm not talking about shuffling your feet around while you grab my butt. I mean real dancing. Cha-cha, rhumba, jitterbug --

question: Face it, honey, some couples dance, some go to Mars. That's life.
answer: I'm serious. We've got two more months in this training rotation, but just as soon as we get home, we're starting lessons. If we never dance, people will think there's something wrong.

question: If they see me dance, they'll know there's something wrong.
answer: You are such a lug. Control, this is Cockpit. Who says report to Micker?

question: Yes. We can design the mission to have a free return capability. It's a long trip, but if you don't land it's the best option.
answer: We're getting ahead of ourselves. You're forgetting the bigger problem. The orbits are all wrong. Our first decent launch window is almost eight months from now.

question: But we can go earlier and get there faster if we reconfigure the payload for extra fuel. We've modelled that, Ray. I've modelled it.
answer: On paper, yeah. But those stresses have never been tested in space.

question: The ship can take it.
answer: I wasn't thinking of just the ship.

question: I've no longer got the right crew.
answer: What do you mean? Bjornstrom can be up here on the next shuttle.

question: Bjornstrom is a geologist. He's good, but not for this. My people just lost eight months of training. This is a different mission, with a different objective.
answer: I haven't been given authorization for a mission yet.

question: But when you are, it ought to be given the best chance for success. I want McConnell to fly right seat.
answer: He's no longer on mission status.

question: Yeah. Because you washed him out.
answer: He washed himself out. He only had to pass a few more psych evaluations, but he refused to take them.

question: Ray, he's the best pilot I ever saw, and you've got him benched at a desk.
answer: Everybody has to pass the psych prelims. No exceptions. Jim knew that.

question: Maggie was his wife. He didn't want to lie on a couch and share her with strangers.
answer: That was his call. But I had to make one too. It was tough as hell, but I'd do it again.

question: His wife wasted away in front of his eyes. What was he supposed to do? Suck it up? Get with the program? What was his crime? That he was upset? That he cried...?
answer: I couldn't trust him! Not in a crisis... I'm sorry Woody, but Jim lost his edge. Are you gonna stand there and tell me Jim McConnell is the same man he was two years ago? You want me to bet four more lives on that?

question: What's that?
answer: That... is the exact chemical composition of my ideal woman.

question: Used to be.
answer: Hey!

question: Now what is it?
answer: A frog.

question: Hey, Skip.
answer: Take a look. What do you make of that?

question: Dust storm. Southern hemisphere, coming from the east... Big fella, too.
answer: Headed for Chryse Planitia.

question: Yup. Could get a little hairy just about landing time...
answer: We'll have to be ready to move fast. Maybe even advance our ETA. Those things can cover the whole planet, and last up to a year.

question: When does SIMA do her fly-by?
answer: Tomorrow morning, about 0600. That's when we find out whether we came all this way for nothing.

question: It's still standing, though. So is the ERV. And look, there's the greenhouse.
answer: We know Luke survived for at least a few hours. Question is, are there any signs of recent activity?

question: There. What the hell are those?
answer: Graves.

question: When they met at the Air Force Academy, it was "love at first flight."
answer: After that, NASA training was tough. All Jim could think about was exploring a heavenly body. More ribald LAUGHTER, as

question: But Maggie, as you can see, kept him on a short leash. Until...
answer: Mission accomplished! Stands in the doorway of his cubicle. Their eyes meet. They both smile, turning back to the video. Remembering.

question: Today we celebrate a new chapter in their story. And guys, it's a pretty historic one.
answer: Let's hear it for the newly-announced Captain and Co-Captain of Mars One. To Jim and Maggie!

question: You okay?
answer: Yeah. I'm good to go. After all these years... Can you believe it? Tomorrow we'll be standing on Mars.

question: You know what? She may have been right. If that wasn't a quake down there, then something else caused it. Or planned it... You're thinking the same thing.
answer: It's never been out of my mind.

question: Jesus. You realize what this means?
answer: She knew, Woody. She was the only one of us that ever thought there might be something down there.

question: Yeah, and we're not leaving until we find out... Deal? Maggie was the best of us.
answer: Range 6783 and closing. 35 minutes till Mars Orbital Capture.

question: Delta V systems initialized.
answer: Charge primary APU.

question: Engaged. Charged.
answer: Select HPU fuel cells for run.

question: Just one goddamn second. Come on, c'mon...
answer: Voice print identification.

question: McConnell!
answer: Accepted. Shutting down artificial gravitational rotation.

question: I don't know! Three minutes? I don't know!
answer: Where's the REMO?

question: The Resupply Module? Why? That's not --
answer: Where is it?!

question: Uh, it's close...
answer: Damn it, how close?!

question: I-I don't know. It'll take time...
answer: We don't have time! Figure it out! Now!

question: Looks again at his display screen, frustrated.
answer: What do you think?

question: We can't catch it. Not like this.
answer: Use the tether. We'll only have one, maybe two shots before she's out of reach.

question: It'll be better if I leave you the gun while I run out to the REMO. I've got enough fuel left for that.
answer: You'll be going too fast.

question: Suit jets gone. But I'm gonna make contact...
answer: At what velocity?

question: Impact's gonna be a little rough.
answer: At what velocity?

question: Thirty-two.
answer: I'm gonna use the gun to slow you.

question: No! You slow me and I'll fall short.
answer: It's too fast, Woody.

question: Tries his suit jets again -- they're empty.
answer: Woody, what's your status?

question: Uh, well, no suit jets and I'm still carrying a good deal of velocity.
answer: As soon as we get hooked up, I'll come get you.

question: Uh, I'd have to say negative on that, Jim.
answer: Negative on the transmission?

question: Releases her thumb from the toggle control. Drifts, staring towards Woody.
answer: Okay, honey...? You gotta go back now.

question: The hell I do.
answer: Watches as it comes shooting down toward him. Looks at the drifting hook, ten agonizing meters away from him. His only life preserver.

question: Hits the button and the wire starts winching fast back into the gun.
answer: What are you doing?

question: I'm gonna jet a little closer and try again.
answer: Terri, you spend any fuel getting closer, you won't get back, and if anyone tries to get you, they'll die too. Honey, please go back. Go back and help everyone get down to the surface.

question: I am not losing you.
answer: I can't let you do it. I can't. I'm sorry.

question: Looks at Woody, two hundred meters away, sensing something different in his voice now, a terrible resolve... Woody...?
answer: Raises his hands to his helmet ring. His eyes shining. I love you, Terri. God how I love you.

question: Ray...? We've got some new data, just coming in. We just -- it doesn't make any sense. We're not sure how to read this.
answer: Data?

question: Yes sir. Telemetry reports the REMO has left its orbit and reached the Martian surface.
answer: Crashed?

question: No sir. Under power.
answer: When?

question: Sixty-three minutes after Mars Recovery went off-line. Sir, the graph reads like a controlled descent. But that doesn't make any --
answer: They used the REMO as a lander. It's McConnell, it's got to be! Nobody else could have pulled this off. Son of a bitch! They're alive.

question: Luke, it's me! Jim McConnell!
answer: You're not here!

question: Luke, it's Jim!
answer: No, no, you're not... you can't be here.

question: Your wife is Debra! Your son is Bobby! You were reading Treasure Island with him...! Don't hurt him!
answer: Phil... Terri... Jim... I don't understand. You're not supposed to be here... Why are you here? Where's Woody?

question: He didn't make it Luke.
answer: Oh no.

question: Luke, what happened here?
answer: We fired the radar. It came. They all died.

question: What came?
answer: They all died, but I was spared. Why? Had to be for a reason. Then, all of a sudden, I knew why I was spared. So somebody would be left to figure out the secret.

question: Luke, we still don't understand.
answer: Come. Comecomecome.

question: When there's time, we'll talk. This way. ...When I came to and dug myself out of the sand, my faceplate was cracked. Leaking badly. I barely made it back to Base. It was weeks before I could work up the nerve to go back out there and look for their... Renee was the only one I could find. But it didn't seem right, somehow, to dig just one grave.
answer: Has it been blowing like this for a while? We saw a big storm from space. But Micker said it was turning south.

question: If it holds course.
answer: This -- whatever it was -- this force. You say it came directly out of the top of the mountain?

question: You don't believe me. That's okay. But I'm not crazy, Jim.
answer: What did you mean by its "secret?" What secret?

question: I don't know. But whatever it is, somebody built it. And not us.
answer: What about the sound? That signal you heard before the explosion?

question: Good, Jim, good. That's the key. Hear the pauses? That's what made me realize it's a pattern -- a repeating pattern.
answer: Mathematical?

question: That's what I thought. There are distinct blocks in the pattern, and within each block the tones come in groups of three. Threethreethree. For months I struggled to analyze it, trying different constructs... Then I thought about dimensions.
answer: X-Y-Z coordinates...

question: It's not a signature.
answer: What?

question: That noise from the Face... It's not a signature. It's a test. It's asking us for the right answer. It wants us to put in the missing pair of chromosomes.
answer: But why?

question: To prove that we're human.
answer: We fired radar into that thing. Concentrated sound waves...

question: How long before it hits?
answer: An hour? Maybe less.

question: How bad?
answer: A storm like that? It could go planetary. And last a year. It'll sock us in, Jim. We won't be able to take off. If that happens, with what few supplies we've got left...? We'll starve to death.

question: Phil, how much longer to prep the ERV?
answer: Maybe forty-five minutes. It'll be tight, but we can make it.

question: Then there's still time for us to get out there and back. Stay here. Continue the repair. If something goes wrong, you get out of here before that storm hits.
answer: Go back... alone?

question: If we're not back in forty-five minutes, I want you to prep and launch. That's 1950 hours.
answer: Jim --

question: It's not a suggestion, it's an order. You understand?
answer: I understand. But --

question: You understand what?
answer: If you're not back by 1950, I prep and launch.

question: Let's go. Phil, do you read me?
answer: Yeah, Jim. Your signal's breaking up a little in the storm, but I read you.

question: We're at the Face. We're gonna need a few minutes here. Same deadline, launch at 1950. With or without us. Do you copy?
answer: Copy that.
